questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough for the past 4 days. During this period, he has had shortness of breath and chest pain that is worse on inspiration. He also reports fatigue and nausea. He has refractory schizophrenia and recurrent asthma attacks. He used to attend college but was expelled after threatening to harm one of his professors 2 months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the left lung. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
1,100/mm3


 Segmented neutrophils

5%


 Eosinophils
0%


 Lymphocytes
93%


 Monocytes
2%


Platelet count
260,000/mm3



Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is used primarily for the treatment of refractory schizophrenia. While it is highly effective in the treatment of schizophrenia, it has serious adverse effects, which can include the life-threatening agranulocytosis (usually defined as an absolute neutrophil count < 500/mm3) seen in this patient. About 1–2% of all patients who begin taking clozapine eventually develop agranulocytosis (usually in the first months of treatment), though this risk falls substantially after the first year. The most common symptoms of agranulocytosis are oral ulcerations, fever, sore throat, malaise, and increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia. A complete blood count should be performed weekly for the first 6 months of treatment, every other week between 6 months and 1 year, and every 4 weeks after 1 year. Patients with mild agranulocytosis require more frequent screenings, while patients with severe agranulocytosis must discontinue the drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for schizophrenia. Adverse effects include weight gain, hyperglycemia, and orthostatic hypotension, but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis. Furthermore, it is rarely used for refractory schizophrenia, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia, which may lead to gynecomastia; agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorpromazine is a medium-potency antipsychotic used for schizophrenia in addition to bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and nausea. It can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic symptoms, but this patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause sedation, metabolic syndrome, hyperglycemia, and weight gain. Agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.
questions.hint: Other side effects of this drug include seizures (dose-dependent risk) and myocarditis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after threatening to harm his roommate earlier today. He says that someone on the radio told him to do so. His family reports that, during the past two years, the patient has become increasingly more withdrawn from family and friends. He states that he has spent the majority of the last year alone in his room “working on a project at home to save the earth from an evil alien power.” There is no family history of serious illness. He has smoked cannabis on a daily basis since the age of 13 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he has a flat affect and his speech is disorganized. An MRI scan of the head is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Periventricular plaques and white matter lesions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periventricular plaques with multiple white matter lesions are the characteristic MRI finding of multiple sclerosis (MS). Though MS can be found incidentally on MRI, the diagnosis is usually made in conjunction with a suggestive patient history (e.g., multiple episodes of weakness, vision changes, or paresthesias). Since this patient does not have any of the typical symptoms of MS, this finding would be unlikely.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Atrophy of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington disease (HD). Though HD can cause psychiatric symptoms such as psychosis, it predominantly causes movement dysfunction (e.g., chorea, dystonia, akinesia, etc.). In addition, HD is inherited in 90% of cases, making it a very unlikely diagnosis in this patient with no significant family medical history.

C) INCORRECT:

Ring-enhancing lesions can be seen with malignancy (e.g. brain metastases, primary CNS lymphoma), infections (e.g. septic emboli, abscesses, neurocysticercosis), or granulomatous disease (e.g. sarcoidosis). This patient's 1-year history of psychotic symptoms, however, is consistent with schizophrenia, which is not associated with ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI.
Image Description:

CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with neurocysticercosis

A rounded peripheral lesion in the right temporoparietal region has a hypodense center (yellow overlay) and thickened enhancing wall (red overlay). There is perilesional low-attenuation edema (green overlay).

These findings are typical of the colloidal-vesicular stage of neurocysticercosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A hyperintense temporal lobe lesion is most commonly seen in patients with herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE). Although HSE can occasionally lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms such as agitation and confusion, it would not cause the psychotic symptoms seen in this patient. Moreover, patients present acutely rather than with chronic symptoms and usually have focal neurologic deficits and fever.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T2-weighted; coronal plane) of a patient with progressive confusion and left upper and lower extremity weakness following 5 days of fever and headache

Cortical and subcortical T2 hyperintense edema with gyral expansion (green overlay) is seen in the right temporal lobe and adjacent insular region. There is mass effect on the right lateral ventricle (arrowheads). Lesser edema involves the left medial temporal and insular regions (hatched green overlay).

Bilateral temporal lobe hyperintensity can be caused by herpes simplex encephalitis and several other viruses. Limbic encephalitis, gliomatosis cerebri, and prolonged status epilepticus are among other causes.

E) CORRECT:

Lateral cerebral ventricle enlargement (in addition to decreased cortical volume) is one of the most consistent MRI findings in schizophrenic patients, with these ventricles being up to 30% larger than normal. The specific reason for ventricular enlargement is not known, but it seems to stem from diffusely decreased cortical volume and shrinkage of the thalamus and putamen. Frequent use of cannabis is a risk factor for psychosis.

Enlarged ventricles are not unique to schizophrenia; they can also be seen in Alzheimer disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus, and as a normal effect of aging in older individuals. However, the sign occurs at a much younger age in patients with schizophrenia in whom the ventricles tend to enlarge at a more rapid rate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with command auditory hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, and negative symptoms (flat affect, social withdrawal) persisting for longer than 6 months, which is consistent with a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 23-year old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother after trying to jump out of a moving car. He says that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been following him for the last 7 months. He recently quit his job at a local consulting firm to work on his mission to rid the world of evil. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/86 mm Hg. On mental status examination, his response to the first question lasts 5 minutes without interruption. He switches topics a number of times and his speech is pressured. He speaks excessively about his plan to “bring absolute justice to the world”. He has a labile affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. A toxicology screen is negative. He is admitted to the hospital and treatment is initiated. One week later, he develops difficulty walking and a tremor that improves with activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's motor symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholinesterase inhibition is the mechanism of action for antidementia medications (e.g., donepezil). Considering the lack of memory dysfunction in this patient, cholinesterase inhibitors would not have been indicated, nor would they have caused EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

B) INCORRECT:

Direct GABA receptor agonists, such as barbiturates, and indirect GABA agonists like benzodiazepines, inhibit neuronal excitability and are used as sedatives. Although benzodiazepines may be considered as a chemical restraint for patients with psychosis exhibiting agitation, they are not used for patients without agitation nor would either drug group cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

C) INCORRECT:

Dopamine agonists, such as ropinirole and pramipexole, may be used in the treatment of Parkinson disease (especially during the early stages). This class of medication would not be given to patients with psychosis since they would further exacerbate psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations.
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

D) CORRECT:

Dopamine-2 receptor antagonism is the main mechanism of action for antipsychotics. All antipsychotics that interact with the D2 receptor can cause EPS, but this effect is particularly pronounced in the use of first-generation antipsychotics due to their high affinity to D2 receptors. Patients who have taken antipsychotics for days to weeks can develop features of pseudoparkinsonism, including tremors, rigidity, and shuffling gait. Antipsychotic-induced pseudoparkinsonism is managed by reducing the dose of the offending drug or switching to a second-generation antipsychotic. If dose reduction or switching is not possible, anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) or nonergot dopamine agonists (e.g., amantadine) can be used.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticholinergic agents (e.g., atropine, benztropine) cause the following side effects: confusion, agitation, hyperthermia, thirst, skin flushing, tachycardia, urinary retention, and dilated, nonreactive pupils. Anticholinergic agents would neither be indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

F) INCORRECT:

Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are used to treat major depressive disorder. They would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

G) INCORRECT:

Among other indications, first-generation H1 antihistamines are used as sedatives to treat insomnia, and second-generation antihistamines are used as antiallergic agents to treat rhinitis and hypersensitivity reactions. The side effects of first-generation H1 antihistamines include sedation and anticholinergic effects, such as dry mouth and eyes, mydriasis, dizziness, tinnitus, urinary retention, and tachycardia. However, they would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

H) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. They can also be used to treat generalized anxiety disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder. However, they are neither routinely used for psychotic disorders, nor do they cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

I) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil is a GABAA receptor antagonist that is used in benzodiazepine overdose as it blocks the same binding site and reverses adverse effects such as confusion, impaired motor coordination, amnesia, drowsiness, and respiratory depression. It would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.
questions.hint: This patient presented with features of schizophrenia (delusions for at least 6 months, pressured and disorganized speech). The development of tremor and difficulty walking following initiation of treatment for schizophrenia are suggestive of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior for the last two years. His mother reports that in the last 2–3 years of high school, her son has spent most of his time in his room playing video games. He does not have any friends and has never had a partner. He usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient states that he prefers being on his own. When asked how much playing video games means to him, he replies that “it's okay.” When his mother starts crying during the visit, he appears indifferent. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. His affect is flattened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by constricted affect and a lack of close friends due to acute discomfort in social interactions and impaired capacity for close relationships. However, further symptoms include distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), as well as eccentric behavior (e.g., peculiar speech), which are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed in patients who present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or negative symptoms that last for more than 1 month but less than 6 months. This patient presents with different symptoms that have been affecting him for over 6 months.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and flattened affect, all of which are features of schizoid personality disorder. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others (see “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table). Of note, the DSM-5 states that personality disorders can be diagnosed in patients < 18 years of age if features have been present for ≥ 1 year. The only exception to this rule is antisocial personality disorder, which can only be diagnosed in patients ≥ 18 years of age.

Personality disorders are characterized by pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive patterns of relating to and perceiving one's self and one's environment that cause significant distress and/or functional impairment. These patterns typically arise during early adolescence, remain stable over time, and are difficult to treat. Treatment options include psychoeducation, psychotherapy, dialectical behavior therapy, group therapy, and/or cognitive therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by lack of empathy and incapacity for intimacy. However, patients are also prone to deceitful, manipulative, and impulsive behavior and they disregard laws and ethical norms if this provides them personal profit or pleasure. Furthermore, the diagnosis can only be made if the individual is ≥ 18 years of age and there is evidence of conduct disorder prior to 15 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder tend to avoid social interactions, but they do this in spite of a wish to establish social relationships because of extreme anxiety and shyness in social situations brought on by feelings of inadequacy and fear of rejection. This patient does not have an inhibited desire to establish personal relationships.

F) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and communication as well as stereotyped behavior, interests, and activities. Reduced ability for empathy and response in social situations could raise the suspicion of ASD, but symptoms of this disorder are typically recognized in early childhood (2–3 years of age) rather than adolescence.

G) INCORRECT:

Social anxiety disorder is characterized by pronounced anxiety and avoidance of social situations that lasts ≥ 6 months. It often develops during adolescence and early adulthood, when patients develop a fear of becoming scrutinized in social situations such as speaking or eating in public. While this patient avoids social interaction, there are no signs to suggest that he is driven to do so by social anxiety or that he suffers from his isolation.

H) INCORRECT:

Internet gaming disorder is included in the DSM-5 under the chapter “Conditions for further study”. While this patient might meet the proposed criterion of a preoccupation with internet games, his involvement in gaming is below the threshold of the other criteria (e.g., withdrawal symptoms, tolerance, unsuccessful attempts to control gaming habit) and his other symptoms rather suggest a different diagnosis.

I) INCORRECT:

Individuals with paranoid personality disorder tend to be socially withdrawn, as this patient is, but they are withdrawn due to a severe distrust and suspiciousness rooted in the notion that others harbor malicious intentions against them. They often perceive even insignificant incidents as directed against them and are quick to perceive attacks on their character that are not apparent to others.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a rare cluster A personality disorder that has some similarities with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time in his room playing online games. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. Rather than doing his coursework, he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon.” Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with social anxiety disorder have anxiety in social situations. However, their anxiety is driven by an intense fear of embarrassment in social situations. Furthermore, this patient's odd beliefs, magical thinking, and unusual clothing could not be explained by this disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with paranoid personality disorder are generally emotionally isolated and have eccentric behavior. However, a key component of paranoid personality disorder is suspicion of and distrust toward others due to the belief that others have malicious intentions. Although this patient is uncomfortable around other people, he is not described as being suspicious of them. Furthermore, paranoid personality disorder is not typically associated with odd and magical thinking.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. On the other hand, disorganized speech results from disorganized thought processes and can manifest as loose associations (illogical, sudden, and frequent changes of topic), word salad (sequence of words without a logical connection), and flight of ideas (quick succession of thoughts), none of which are evident in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a cluster A personality disorder.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his mother found him locked in his room stammering about a government conspiracy to brainwash him in subterranean tunnels. His mother says that he has never done this before, but 6 months ago he stopped going to classes and was subsequently suspended from college. She reports that he has become increasingly taciturn over the course of the past month. He drinks one to two beers daily and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 3 years. He occasionally smokes marijuana. His father was diagnosed with schizophrenia at the age of 25 years. The patient has had no friends or social contacts other than his mother since he was suspended. He appears unkempt and aloof. On mental status examination, he is disorganized and shows blunt speech. He says his mood is “good.” He does not hear voices and has no visual or tactile hallucinations. Toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is a favorable prognostic factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of negative symptoms (flat affect, catatonia, social withdrawal) is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia, especially if they dominate the overall picture of psychotic symptoms. This patient shows poverty of thought, appears unkempt, and has withdrawn socially, putting him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease. His delusion is a positive symptom.

B) INCORRECT:

The age of onset correlates with long-term outcomes in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. Older age at the time of disease onset is associated with a more favorable prognosis. This patient is only 18 years old, which is rather associated with a poor prognosis.

C) CORRECT:

The rapid onset of symptoms in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia is associated with a more favorable long-term prognosis than a gradual onset. This patient first started showing changes in behavior 6 months ago (skipping class, social withdrawal) and now presents with an acute, first-time psychosis with delusions and disorganized thinking. While he has several negative prognostic factors present (negative symptoms, young age, positive family history), the rapid onset of his symptoms is a positive prognostic factor.

It is important to remember that the diagnosis of schizophrenia requires a total duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months (including periods of prodromal or residual symptoms) and ≥ 1 month of active symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive family history is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. This patient's father had schizophrenia, putting him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Male sex is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.

F) INCORRECT:

The concomitant use of recreational drugs is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. His use of cannabis and alcohol puts him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease. Although the exact mechanism is unclear, frequent cannabis use in early adolescence is associated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia.
questions.hint: The patient shows evidence of delusions, social withdrawal, and disorganized thinking that severely affect his daily functioning. The most likely diagnosis is schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago, he was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with trifluoperazine and cognitive behavioral therapy was initiated. He reports feeling better since starting treatment but says that he has recently developed difficulty with daily tasks, such as typing and picking up the phone. He works as an administrative assistant. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He drinks two beers daily and does not use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows rigidity and shuffling gait. On mental status examination, his speech is normal, and his thought processes are linear with no disturbances of thought content or suicidal ideation. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. After discontinuing trifluoperazine, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy at this time?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is necessary at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is a very effective second-generation antipsychotic but is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (i.e., persistent symptoms despite taking 2 different antipsychotics at their maximum doses for ≥ 6 weeks) because of the risk for significant side effects (e.g., agranulocytosis).

B) CORRECT:

The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an FGA or a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) can be used. Because this patient developed extrapyramidal symptoms due to treatment with an FGA, the drug should be discontinued and treatment should be replaced by an SGA such as quetiapine. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Paliperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that can be used to treat schizophrenia. For maintenance therapy in schizophrenia, an intramuscular injection of a depot preparation of an antipsychotic is only considered if the patient has poor medication adherence to daily oral antipsychotic medication. This patient has no history of medication nonadherence.

An intramuscular antipsychotic injection is also used for the acute management of psychosis if the patient is severely agitated. This patient is calm and not in a psychotic state.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral amantadine is a dopamine agonist used to treat pseudoparkinsonism in patients taking antipsychotic drugs. However, it is only indicated if pseudoparkinsonism persists after stopping the causative drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency FGA that can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, this patient has previously developed extrapyramidal symptoms with an FGA. Therefore, a different treatment option should be considered.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment. Discontinuing antipsychotic therapy puts the patient at risk of relapse.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia developed extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., pseudoparkinsonism) following treatment with trifluoperazine, a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA).

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a homeless shelter because of bizarre behavior. He avoids contact with others and has complained to the supervising staff that he thinks people are reading his mind. Three days ago, he unplugged every electrical appliance on his floor of the shelter because he believed they were being used to transmit messages about him to others. The patient has schizophrenia and has been prescribed risperidone but has been unable to adhere to his medications because of his unstable living situation. He is disheveled and malodorous. His thought process is disorganized, and he does not make eye contact. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker, can be used to reduce involuntary movements in akathisia, an adverse effect of antipsychotic use. However, this patient has no evidence of akathisia.

B) INCORRECT:

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is used in the management of patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia, particularly those with persistent suicidality. This patient's symptoms are due to nonadherence rather than refractory schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral haloperidol, a first-generation typical antipsychotic, is used in the treatment of schizophrenia. However, this patient has already been prescribed risperidone (an atypical antipsychotic), and haloperidol is unlikely to be beneficial if he remains nonadherent.

D) INCORRECT:

Benztropine is used in the management of extrapyramidal syndromes associated with antipsychotic use (e.g., dystonia, akathisia), and intramuscular administration is preferred in the acute setting. However, this patient has none of these manifestations.

E) INCORRECT:

Diazepam, a benzodiazepine, can be used in the management of acute extrapyramidal syndromes associated with antipsychotic use (e.g., dystonia, akathisia). However, this patient has none of these manifestations.

F) CORRECT:

Long-acting injectable antipsychotics, such as intramuscular (IM) risperidone, are the preferred pharmacologic strategy for treating patients with schizophrenia who have frequent relapses due to medication nonadherence. The use of long-acting injectable antipsychotics is associated with improved treatment adherence due to a reduced need for daily medications. IM risperidone is generally administered every 2 weeks but continues to be absorbed 4–6 weeks after injection.

G) INCORRECT:

Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine, can be used in the management of acute extrapyramidal syndromes associated with antipsychotic use (e.g., dystonia, akathisia). However, this patient has none of these manifestations.
questions.hint: This patient's unstable living situation and nonadherence with his medication pose a challenge for treatment. Special consideration of his social circumstances should be taken when choosing a medication for him.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because she thinks that her “right wrist is broken.” She says that she has severe pain and that “the bone is sticking out.” She has not had any trauma to the wrist. Her medical records indicate that she was diagnosed with schizophrenia 2 years ago and treated with olanzapine; she has not filled any prescriptions over the past 4 months. Three weeks ago, she stopped going to work because she “did not feel like getting up” in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right wrist shows no visible injury; there is no warmth, swelling, or erythema. Range of motion is limited by pain. On mental status examination, she has a flat affect. Her speech is pressured and she frequently changes the topic. She has short- and long-term memory deficits. Attention and concentration are poor. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An x-ray of the wrist shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns?

choices.text: “I cannot see any injury of your wrist, and the physical exam and the x-ray don't show any injury. I imagine that feeling as if your wrist was broken may be very uncomfortable. Can you tell me more about what it feels like?”
"I can imagine that you are uncomfortable. That certainly looks painful. Let's take care of this injury first and then we should talk about your problems getting up in the morning."
“It seems as though you are having a schizophrenia relapse. If you don't follow my recommendations and take your medications, you will most likely have further and possibly more severe episodes.”

"You are clearly distressed. However, your tests do not suggest a physical problem that can be addressed with medications or surgery. I suggest that we meet and evaluate your symptoms on a regular basis."

"Your physical examination findings and the x-ray cannot explain your symptoms, suggesting a psychological rather than a physical problem. I will prescribe olanzapine, which should relieve your symptoms."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Establishing a therapeutic alliance is essential when taking care of patients with delusions. An empathy-based approach, which acknowledges the patient's emotional state, is an effective means of reinforcing the stability of therapeutic alliance and medication compliance. In addition, healthcare providers should avoid validating delusions or confronting patients about the delusional nature of their complaints.

B) INCORRECT:

Validating the patient's delusion would perpetuate the patient's beliefs rather than addressing the underlying cause (psychiatric disorder).

C) INCORRECT:

Although the patient's symptoms are likely secondary to a schizophrenia relapse, this response does not address the patient's symptoms. Efforts to build a trusting relationship that will increase the chances of medication compliance should be pursued first.

D) INCORRECT:

Meeting on a regular basis is indicated in patients with somatoform disorder. This patient's history of schizophrenia and medication nonadherence suggests that she is experiencing a somatic delusion secondary to a psychotic episode rather than a somatoform disorder. In the current setting, a statement that acknowledges her emotional state in an empathetic way is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

This response challenges the patient's subjective experience of symptoms and undermines her trust in her healthcare provider, thus hampering the establishment of a therapeutic relationship.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a somatic delusion (broken wrist), flattened affect, avolition, disorganized and pressured speech, poor concentration, and memory deficits, which suggests an acute psychotic episode. Her history of schizophrenia and discontinuation of antipsychotic treatment for the last four months further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the emergency department requesting an abortion. She hears voices telling her that she needs "to undergo a cleanse because she has been visited by a demon." She experiences daytime sleepiness because she repeatedly wakes up at night. She says that she is no longer interested in activities that she used to enjoy. About 2 months ago, her psychiatrist switched her medication from aripiprazole to quetiapine because it was not effective even at maximum dose. She currently takes quetiapine at the maximum dose. She appears disheveled. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows accelerated speech, and the patient regularly switches the conversation to the natural habitat of bees. She has no suicidal or homicidal ideation. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Toxicology screening is negative. Pelvic ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy at 15 weeks' gestation. Following admission to the hospital, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Most guidelines suggest a clozapine trial if patients have persistent positive symptoms of schizophrenia despite trials of at least 6 weeks' duration with two different antipsychotics at their maximum doses. Ideally, this patient should taper off quetiapine and then start clozapine. However, if this is not a realistic option due to the risk of uncontrolled schizophrenia symptoms, combination therapy with close monitoring during the transition period is possible. Most studies have found that prenatal exposure to antipsychotics, including quetiapine and clozapine, does not increase the risk of physical malformations. However, administration during the third trimester can cause withdrawal symptoms in the newborn. The decision to initiate or continue antipsychotic therapy during pregnancy should always be discussed with the patient's partner and/or family members.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of active psychosis (e.g., auditory hallucinations, delusions, and accelerated and disorganized speech) impair her decision-making capacity and thus raise suspicion that her request for an abortion does not arise from a stable choice that reflects her wishes. Her schizophrenia should be effectively treated before considering the request for an abortion.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient might benefit from cognitive behavioral therapy as an adjunct treatment once her schizophrenia has stabilized, she must first recover from her acute psychotic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Ziprasidone belongs to the second-generation antipsychotics, which are commonly used to treat schizophrenia in nonpregnant individuals. In pregnant patients, newer second-generation antipsychotics are not routinely recommended; older generations of antipsychotics with a greater evidence base are preferable. Moreover, this patient has persistent positive symptoms of schizophrenia despite trials of at least 6 weeks' duration with two different antipsychotics (aripiprazole and risperidone) at their maximum doses. Therefore, she meets the criteria for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, for which ziprasidone is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

While older antipsychotics such as haloperidol are safe to use during pregnancy, they are not the preferred option for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Furthermore, long-term injectable (depot form) antipsychotics are generally only considered in patients with poor treatment adherence. This patient takes her medication regularly and, therefore, would not benefit from long-term injectable haloperidol. In addition, because of the risk of side effects, patients should not be started on long-acting injectable antipsychotics without a trial of the oral formulation of the same medication first.

F) INCORRECT:

Lithium is used as first-line therapy for acute mania, as maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder as well as augmentation therapy in treatment-resistant depression. Although this patient displays both symptoms of depression (sleep disturbance, anhedonia) and mania (accelerated and disorganized speech), these are likely a manifestation of her schizophrenia. Lithium is not an effective monotherapy or add-on therapy for the treatment of this condition. In addition, observational studies have found an association between fetal lithium exposure and teratogenic birth defects, though the increase in absolute risk is small.
questions.hint: This pregnant woman shows features of recurring psychosis (e.g., auditory hallucinations, delusions, and accelerated and disorganized speech) despite trying two antipsychotic medications at their maximum doses, which is consistent with treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been hearing voices in her apartment during the past year. She also reports that she has been receiving warning messages in newspaper articles during this period. She states that “someone is trying to kill me.” She avoids meeting her family and friends because they do not believe her. She does not use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a normal affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA). Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy. The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an SGA (with the exception of clozapine) or a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA) can be used as first-line treatment. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

B) INCORRECT:

A mood stabilizer such as lithium carbonate is a first-line option for maintenance treatment of psychiatric disorders associated with mania such as schizoaffective disorder and bipolar disorder type 1. Patients with either of these conditions can have delusions and auditory hallucinations during the manic episode. However, other features characteristic of mania such as increased talkativeness, flight of ideas, easy distractibility, grandiosity, increased impulsivity, and psychomotor agitation are not present in this patient. Mood stabilizers are not typically used to treat schizophrenia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

An SSRI such as sertraline is used as a first-line drug to treat major depressive disorder (MDD) and anxiety disorders. A variant of MDD called major depressive disorder with psychotic features (psychotic depression) can present with delusions and auditory hallucinations. However, the patient with psychotic depression would have a sad or flattened affect and other features characteristic of depression such as feelings of worthlessness, anhedonia, diminished concentration, sleep disturbance, weight change, or suicidal ideation. SSRIs are not used to treat psychosis in schizophrenia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

SSRIs can be used to treat postpsychotic depression, which can occur in patients with schizophrenia after the resolution of psychotic symptoms. SSRIs can also be used as an adjunct to treat depression in patients with schizoaffective disorder, which can present similarly with features of psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Midazolam can be used to sedate agitated or aggressive patients. Patients with schizophrenia may become agitated or aggressive during a psychotic episode. This patient, however, is neither agitated nor aggressive. Moreover, a short-acting benzodiazepine such as midazolam is not used for maintenance therapy in any psychiatric disorder.

Long-acting benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam, lorazepam) can be used as an adjunct to SSRIs or SNRIs in patients with severe anxiety disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is a very potent second-generation antipsychotic but it is associated with agranulocytosis. Therefore, it is typically reserved for use in treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
questions.hint: This patient with auditory hallucinations and delusions (ideas of reference, delusions of persecution) for more than 6 months meets the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his sister because she has noticed that he has been behaving differently over the past 4 weeks. Today, the patient attempted to set their house on fire while yelling that he was trying to “save us all.” The patient has a history of psychotic symptoms treated with aripiprazole. His sister states that he stopped taking his medications about 3 weeks ago. He works as a dishwasher but has not been to work for several days. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows a blunted affect. Throughout the interview, the patient continuously stares at the ceiling and makes little eye contact with the physician. When asked about the incident today, he states that he has been hearing the voice of “the great one” who has informed him that aliens are in his neighborhood in the form of rats and cockroaches that need to be “torched to prevent the alien invasion.” He is refusing treatment and insists on going home. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer aripiprazole and follow-up after 24 hours
Refer the patient to a psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy
Report the patient to the local police
Ask the patient's sister to convince him to stay overnight

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administering aripiprazole and following up after 24 hours may be appropriate for a stable patient who is nonadherent with home medications. However, this patient is experiencing an acute psychotic episode, during which he tried to set his house on fire. He is a danger to himself and others, which is why discharging him is inappropriate at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Risperidone injected intramuscularly every 2 weeks (i.e., depot therapy) is a long-term treatment option for patients with schizophrenia who have a history of poor adherence. This patient's nonadherence with oral pharmacological treatment makes him a good candidate for maintenance therapy with long-acting injectable antipsychotics, which should be started following initial stabilization in order to prevent future relapse. However, at this point, he is experiencing an acute psychotic episode and requires more urgent treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Referral to a psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy is an important adjunctive treatment for patients with schizophrenia, as it helps to avoid relapse of psychotic symptoms. However, this patient is experiencing an acute psychotic episode and requires more urgent treatment.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is in the midst of an acute psychotic episode, during which he tried to set his house on fire. Because he represents an immediate danger to himself and to others, the most appropriate next step would be to involuntarily hospitalize him and initiate treatment with short-acting antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, haloperidol). This patient's history of nonadherence with oral pharmacological treatment makes him a good candidate for maintenance therapy with long-acting injectable antipsychotics, which should be started following initial stabilization in order to prevent future relapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Reporting the patient to the local police is not appropriate, as this patient is in the midst of a psychotic episode and requires immediate medical treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

While convincing the patient to voluntarily stay overnight may improve his adherence and help to establish a therapeutic relationship, it is not appropriate to place this responsibility on his sister. Furthermore, voluntariness is not required for hospitalization of this patient as he is acutely psychotic and represents a danger to himself and to others, evidenced by the attempt to set his house on fire.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of psychotic illness presents with auditory hallucinations, delusions, blunted affect, and apathetic behavior, strongly suggesting an acute psychotic episode of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, he was admitted to the hospital and underwent treatment for a psychotic episode. He has had one prior psychotic episode 3 years ago. He is currently undergoing weekly sessions of cognitive behavioral therapy and his only medication is risperidone. He lives with his mother and two younger siblings; his father left the family when the patient was a teenager. The patient works about 20 hours each week in a fast food restaurant. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He does not use illicit drugs. He appears well. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has a neutral affect and describes his mood as “decent.” His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. His thought process is organized and there are no abnormalities of thought content. Short-term and long-term memory are intact. Attention and concentration are normal; he is able to perform serial sevens and can repeat seven digits forward and five digits in reverse on a digit span test. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to prevent readmission of this patient for his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Family therapy is indicated in patients who have recently undergone a relapse of psychosis and have an active relationship with their partners or families. This intervention focuses on identifying and correcting dysfunctional family dynamics in order to reduce conflict, improve communication skills, and help family members to accommodate one another. This therapy further enables family members to recognize the signs of schizophrenia and to be more understanding of the patient's behavior. The main goals of treatment are to reduce symptoms and lower the risk of relapse of psychosis, hospitalization, and nonadherence to medication. Family therapy should only begin when the patient is no longer in a psychotic state and counseling can last anywhere from a few months to several years, typically with weekly sessions.

B) INCORRECT:

Social skills training (SST) is recommended for patients with schizophrenia who have difficulty with daily activities (e.g., social interaction, independent living, employment). This patient has a regular job and attends weekly sessions of cognitive-behavioral therapy, indicating adequate daily functioning. Therefore, SST is not required for this patient. Also, SST is not effective in preventing relapses of psychosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Exposure and response prevention therapy is used in patients with anxiety disorders (e.g., specific phobia) and obsessive-compulsive disorder. This patient has no symptoms of an anxiety disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder, and exposure and response prevention therapy is not used in the treatment of schizophrenia.

D) INCORRECT:

Assertive community treatment is an intensive intervention that is effective in preventing relapse of psychosis in patients with schizophrenia who have profound functional and behavioral impairment (e.g., frequent hospitalization, homelessness, legal troubles due to violent behavior and/or substance use) despite psychiatric care. This patient has stable housing, a regular job, and no signs of functional or behavioral impairment; therefore, he requires another type of psychotherapy to prevent relapses of psychosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cognitive remediation therapy (CRT) may be used in patients with schizophrenia who also have cognitive deficits (e.g., in attention, planning, and memory). Because this patient's attention and concentration are normal, his memory intact, and his thought process organized, CRT is not indicated. In addition, CRT is ineffective at preventing relapses of psychosis.
questions.hint: This form of supportive psychotherapy can improve interpersonal relationships.

questions.text: One week after admission for an acute manic episode with psychotic features, a 27-year-old woman is found sitting on a chair in her hospital room and staring blindly at the ceiling with her head bent backwards. The nurse states that the patient has not changed her position since she first saw her several hours ago this morning. The day before, the patient participated actively in a group psychotherapy session and took a yoga class offered in the psychiatric unit. She has a history of bipolar disorder and has been hospitalized for multiple episodes of acute mania and major depression in the past 5 years. She takes lithium for long-term maintenance treatment. Since admission, she has received several doses of haloperidol, which has gradually reduced her manic symptoms. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. The patient does not react to the physician when she is called by her name or asked to stand up from the chair. Examination shows resistance to passive limb movement. After repositioning, the limbs remain in their new locations. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is the treatment for severe lithium toxicity, which can manifest acutely with behavioral changes including speech impairment. However, features of catatonia would not be expected. Instead, patients present with confusion, seizures, ataxia, neuromuscular excitability (hyperreflexia, tremors), and/or gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting).

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous benzodiazepines such as lorazepam are the first-line therapy for nonmalignant catatonia. If nonmalignant catatonia fails to respond to benzodiazepine therapy within a week, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is indicated. For malignant catatonia and for nonmalignant catatonia due to a mood disorder with psychotic features, as seen here, ECT is a first-line treatment; however, benzodiazepine therapy must still be initiated while preparations for ECT are being made. The underlying psychiatric condition must also be treated with appropriate pharmacotherapy with the exception of antipsychotic therapy (dopamine blocking drugs), which should only be initiated after catatonia resolves. Additionally, patients with catatonia should receive deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis, preventive measures against pressure ulcers, adequate hydration, and if necessary, specialized nutrition support.

It is often difficult to distinguish malignant catatonia from neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) because both conditions typically occur in patients with psychiatric disease and manifest with fever, diaphoresis, autonomic instability, catatonic features, and similar laboratory findings (e.g., increased creatinine kinase, leukocytosis). A prodrome of excitement and agitation, the presence of symptoms when the patient is not on antipsychotics, and the absence of lead-pipe rigidity are features more consistent with malignant catatonia. In case of doubt, treat the patient for both conditions; NMS is primarily treated with dantrolene and bromocriptine and by discontinuing the causative antipsychotic.

C) INCORRECT:

Benztropine is not used to treat catatonia but rather acute dystonia, akathisia, and bradykinesia, which are extrapyramidal side effects of typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Acute dystonia, which occurs hours to days after initiating haloperidol, can cause muscle stiffness, abnormal position of the head and neck (due to torticollis), and speech impairment (due to spasm of the jaw, tongue and/or laryngeal muscles). However, patients with extrapyramidal side effects from antipsychotics would be responsive, unlike this patient with mutism, stupor, and negativism.

D) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole, an atypical antipsychotic, can be used to treat manic episodes of bipolar disorder. Although treatment of the underlying psychiatric disorder is a part of the treatment of catatonia, dopamine blocking drugs such as antipsychotics should be avoided until catatonia resolves. Moreover, this patient has already experienced a decline in manic symptoms as a result of haloperidol therapy; additional antipsychotic therapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is not used to treat catatonia. Instead, it is indicated for malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). NMS can occur a few days following the administration of antipsychotics such as haloperidol and cause catatonic features. However, patients with NMS would have fever, diaphoresis, and autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, tachypnea).

F) INCORRECT:

Oral cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which can also cause resistance to passive movements on examination (due to muscle rigidity). Features of catatonia, such as waxy flexibility, posturing, mutism, and negativism, would not be expected. Instead, patients would have psychomotor agitation, neuromuscular excitability (hyperreflexia, tremors), fever, diaphoresis, and autonomic instability (tachycardia, tachypnea). Moreover, serotonin syndrome typically occurs due to a combination of two or more serotonergic drugs, e.g., antidepressants, tramadol, triptans, ondansetron, meperidine, and dextromethorphan. Haloperidol (a typical antipsychotic) and lithium are not serotonergic drugs.
questions.hint: This patient shows akinesis, abnormal posturing, mutism, negativism, stupor, and waxy flexibility, all of which are classic signs of catatonia. Catatonia can occur in a number of psychiatric diseases (e.g., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, major depressive disorder) as well as organic conditions (e.g., encephalopathy).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 7-month history of bizarre behavior. His mother reports that the patient has become increasingly suspicious of his friends because “they all collaborate against us.” Over the past 4 months, he has spent most of the day outside of his apartment because he believes that the CIA is using special surveillance techniques to spy on him at home. He recently lost his job as a senior project manager at a renowned telecommunications company because he did not attend work for 2 weeks and failed to notify his superiors. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He used to smoke marijuana on a regular basis but quit 5 months ago. He appears thin and agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and suspicious. His speech is disorganized. During the examination, he suddenly interrupts the physician and says: “Yes, we can trust the doctor. The doctor is my friend.” This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by which of the following types of dopamine dysregulation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dopamine release in the tuberoinfundibular projections inhibits the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary. Decreased dopaminergic activity in this pathway causes hyperprolactinemia, which typically manifests with gynecomastia, galactorrhea, and erectile dysfunction. Hyperprolactinemia is also associated with an increased risk of depression but is not known to increase the risk of psychosis. This patient's symptoms are caused by the dysfunction of different dopaminergic projections.

B) CORRECT:

Increased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic projections is thought to be primarily responsible for the positive symptoms of schizophrenia. Antipsychotics, which primarily inhibit D2 receptors, are effective in alleviating the positive symptoms of schizophrenia by decreasing the dopaminergic activity in this pathway. Antipsychotics are less effective at treating the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., apathy, flat affect, avolition), which are primarily caused by decreased dopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway. The adverse effects of antipsychotics include parkinsonism and hyperprolactinemia, which are caused by the antagonistic effects of antipsychotics on the dopamine receptors in the nigrostriatal and tuberoinfundibular pathways, respectively. The mesolimbic pathway plays an important role in reward- and aversion-related cognition, and dysfunction in this pathway is also implicated in the pathophysiology of substance use disorders.

The antiserotonergic activity of atypical antipsychotics and findings in patients with schizophrenia such as decreased levels of glutamate decarboxylase (GABA-producing enzyme) in the hippocampus and decreased expression of NMDA receptors suggest that neurotransmitters other than dopamine may also be involved in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia. However, the exact role of these neurotransmitters is unclear.

C) INCORRECT:

Dopamine release in the nigrostriatal projections modulates motor activity and certain cognitive functions. Decreased dopaminergic activity in this pathway is responsible for certain features of parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, difficulty initiating movements). Increased rather than decreased dopaminergic activity in the nigrostriatal pathway has recently been shown to be central to the pathophysiology of the positive symptoms of psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The projections of the locus ceruleus to other parts of the CNS are noradrenergic neurons, not dopaminergic neurons. Increased noradrenergic activity in these pathways is implicated in the symptoms of anxiety disorders, not psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Dopamine release in the mesocortical projections is required for normal executive functions. Decreased dopaminergic activity in this pathway is responsible for the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., apathy, flat affect, avolition). This patient has schizophrenia but primarily has positive symptoms (e.g., delusions, auditory hallucinations), which are caused by dysfunction of different dopaminergic projections.
questions.hint: Persecutory delusions and auditory hallucinations persisting for > 6 months are consistent with a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he was started on increasing doses of risperidone because of behavioral changes. His mother now reports that he has become increasingly suspicious of the mail carrier, who he believes is “a secret agent from the CIA who is spying on our family.” The patient has been hospitalized for similar episodes in the past. He is currently at the maximum dose of risperidone. Previous treatment with quetiapine was not effective. His mother reports that he has been living with her since he lost his job 3 months ago. His mother has seen him taking his medications regularly. Last month, his girlfriend left him after he attacked her because he believed that she was cheating on him. He used to smoke marijuana on a regular basis but stopped 1 year ago. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he does not respond to any questions or instructions and continues to look to the left while nodding and smiling. Laboratory studies, including a urine toxicology screen, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue medication and refer for cognitive behavioral therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term injectable (depot form) antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) may be considered in patients with schizophrenia with poor treatment adherence. This patient takes his medication regularly and, therefore, would not benefit from long-term injectable haloperidol.

B) CORRECT:

Clozapine is usually the first-line therapy for treatment-resistant schizophrenia because it is more effective than other antipsychotics. Clozapine is associated with an increased risk of agranulocytosis. Therefore, the benefits and risks of treatment, as well as the patient's ability to adhere to treatment and follow-ups, must be weighed and discussed with the patient and their family. Before initiating clozapine, the leukocyte count and differential should also be assessed; regular monitoring is indicated during treatment. Patients should have an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) > 1500 cells/μL before beginning treatment with clozapine. Additionally, monitoring for adverse metabolic effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia) is also recommended since atypical antipsychotics also increase the risk of metabolic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Electroconvulsive therapy and antipsychotic therapy are indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia in patients with low absolute neutrophil counts and for schizophrenia with catatonia, neither of which is the case here.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral lithium is a mood stabilizer that is indicated for both the acute and long-term management of mania. Although this patient is agitated and distracted, he lacks additional symptoms of mania (e.g., flight of ideas, elevated mood). Occasionally, other mood stabilizers, like lamotrigine, are used in combination with antipsychotics in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, oral lithium is not the first-line therapy in the management of such patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be used in combination with antipsychotic drugs in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, CBT is less effective when used alone.

F) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine can be used to treat schizophrenic patients with concurrent depression or anxiety, neither of which is seen in this man. This patient has treatment-resistant schizophrenia, for which SSRIs are not effective.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is defined as ongoing positive symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) despite two antipsychotic trials of ≥ 6 weeks at the maximum dose.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia asks about a trial without medication. He has been stable for the past 3 years while taking 4 mg of risperidone daily. He is doing well at work and lives independently. He initially gained 3 kg of body weight after starting risperidone but has had no other unwanted effects from the medication; his weight has been stable for the past 2 years. He says he wants to stop the risperidone “on principle,” without being able to explain his aim. A previous lowering of his risperidone dosage resulted in a recurrence of psychotic symptoms that brought him significant distress and caused him to miss work for one month.
In addition to an ongoing dialogue with the patient, which one of the following treatment approaches is recommended?

choices.text: Discontinue risperidone and monitor for symptoms of relapse
Change the risperidone dosing from daily use to as needed
Explore his concerns, but recommend continuing the risperidone
Reduce the dose of risperidone to 2 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of risperidone, using it only as needed, or discontinuing it completely would significantly increase the risk for relapse. Also, when a patient starts to relapse, insight and treatment adherence are often compromised.

B) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of risperidone, using it only as needed, or discontinuing it completely would significantly increase the risk for relapse. Also, when a patient starts to relapse, insight and treatment adherence are often compromised.

C) INCORRECT:

Switching to a different antipsychotic medication is appropriate if a patient has unacceptable adverse effects or does not respond to his or her current regimen. This patient, however, is having a good response to his current dose of risperidone, without major adverse effects. Switching to another agent also raises risk, because the risks and benefits of any new drug are unknown. Olanzapine may be a particularly unfavorable choice; it carries a relatively high risk for weight gain and may result in the development of metabolic syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

After a psychotic episode, continued treatment with an antipsychotic agent can significantly reduce the risk for relapse among individuals with schizophrenia. In a systematic review of published papers comparing continuation of antipsychotic therapy to discontinuation, the relapse rate at 7 to 12 months was 24% with continuation versus 61% with discontinuation. When discussing whether or not to discontinue an antipsychotic medication, clinicians should inform patients about the potential relapse rate.

To sustain symptom remission, maintain level of functioning, and protect quality of life, guidelines call for prescribing the minimum effective dosage of an antipsychotic medication for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia. In this scenario, the patient is on the minimum effective dose, as evidenced by the return of psychotic symptoms when the dose was reduced in the past.

Key learning point: The most appropriate course of action when a patient with schizophrenia achieves one year of symptom remission on a minimum effective antipsychotic dosage without experiencing substantial adverse effects is to continue the current regimen, given the high rate of relapse without treatment and the demonstrated tolerability and efficacy of the current treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of risperidone, using it only as needed, or discontinuing it completely would significantly increase the risk for relapse. Also, when a patient starts to relapse, insight and treatment adherence are often compromised.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the office by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people and he does not have any friends. He spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that sometimes there are signs of their presence, for example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon”. Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

Key learning point: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric behavior, odd beliefs or magical thinking, social anxiety, and lack of close relationships without frank psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office because she has been hearing voices in her apartment during the past year. She also reports that she has been receiving warning messages in newspaper articles during this period. She states that “someone is trying to kill me.” She avoids meeting her family and friends because they do not believe her. She does not use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a normal affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA). Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy. The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an SGA (with the exception of clozapine) or a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA) can be used as first-line treatment. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Key learning point: Second-generation antipsychotics, such as quetiapine, are first-line agents for long-term maintenance therapy in schizophrenia due to their efficacy and lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to first-generation antipsychotics.

B) INCORRECT:

A mood stabilizer such as lithium carbonate is a first-line option for maintenance treatment of psychiatric disorders associated with mania such as schizoaffective disorder and bipolar disorder type 1. Patients with either of these conditions can have delusions and auditory hallucinations during the manic episode. However, other features characteristic of mania such as increased talkativeness, flight of ideas, easy distractibility, grandiosity, increased impulsivity, and psychomotor agitation are not present in this patient. An SSRI such as sertraline is used as a first-line drug to treat major depressive disorder (MDD) and anxiety disorders. SSRIs can be used to treat postpsychotic depression, which can occur in patients with schizophrenia after the resolution of psychotic symptoms. SSRIs can also be used as an adjunct to treat depression in patients with schizoaffective disorder, which can present similarly with features of psychosis.
