Midazolam can be used to sedate agitated or aggressive patients. Patients with schizophrenia may become agitated or aggressive during a psychotic episode. This patient, however, is neither agitated nor aggressive. Moreover, a short-acting benzodiazepine such as midazolam is not used for maintenance therapy in any psychiatric disorder.

Long-acting benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam, lorazepam) can be used as an adjunct to SSRIs or SNRIs in patients with severe anxiety disorders.

Clozapine is a very potent second-generation antipsychotic but it is associated with agranulocytosis. Therefore, it is typically reserved for use in treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his mother found him locked in his room stammering about a government conspiracy to brainwash him in subterranean tunnels. His mother says that he has never done this before, but 6 months ago he stopped going to classes and was subsequently suspended from college. She reports that he has become increasingly taciturn over the past month. His father was diagnosed with schizophrenia at the age of 25 years. The patient has had no social contacts since he was suspended. He appears unkempt and aloof. On mental status examination, he is disorganized and shows blunt speech. He denies any hallucinations. Which of the following is a favorable prognostic factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of negative symptoms (flat affect, catatonia, social withdrawal) is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia, especially if they dominate the overall picture of psychotic symptoms. This patient shows poverty of thought, appears unkempt, and has withdrawn socially, putting him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease. His delusion is a positive symptom.

B) INCORRECT:

The age of onset correlates with long-term outcomes in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. Older age at the time of disease onset is associated with a more favorable prognosis. This patient is only 18 years old, which is rather associated with a poor prognosis.

C) CORRECT:

The rapid onset of symptoms in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia is associated with a more favorable long-term prognosis than a gradual onset. This patient first started showing changes in behavior 6 months ago (skipping class, social withdrawal) and now presents with an acute, first-time psychosis with delusions and disorganized thinking. While he has several negative prognostic factors present (negative symptoms, young age, positive family history), the rapid onset of his symptoms is a positive prognostic factor.

It is important to remember that the diagnosis of schizophrenia requires a total duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months (including periods of prodromal or residual symptoms) and ≥ 1 month of active symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive family history is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. This patient's father had schizophrenia, putting him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Male sex is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.
questions.hint: The patient shows evidence of delusions, social withdrawal, and disorganized thinking that severely affect his daily functioning. The most likely diagnosis is schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with refractory schizophrenia comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough for the past 4 days. During this period, he has had shortness of breath and chest pain that is worse on inspiration. He also reports fatigue and nausea. He used to attend college but was expelled after threatening to harm one of his professors 2 months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the left lung. Laboratory studies show agranulocytosis. Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?

A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is used primarily for the treatment of refractory schizophrenia. While it is highly effective in the treatment of schizophrenia, it has serious adverse effects, which can include the life-threatening agranulocytosis (usually defined as an absolute neutrophil count < 500/mm3) seen in this patient. About 1–2% of all patients who begin taking clozapine eventually develop agranulocytosis (usually in the first months of treatment), though this risk falls substantially after the first year. The most common symptoms of agranulocytosis are oral ulcerations, fever, sore throat, malaise, and increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia. A complete blood count should be performed weekly for the first 6 months of treatment, every other week between 6 months and 1 year, and every 4 weeks after 1 year. Patients with mild agranulocytosis require more frequent screenings, while patients with severe agranulocytosis must discontinue the drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for schizophrenia. Adverse effects include weight gain, hyperglycemia, and orthostatic hypotension, but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis. Furthermore, it is rarely used for refractory schizophrenia, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency antipsychotic that can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic adverse effects but it does not typically cause agranulocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia, which may lead to gynecomastia; agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorpromazine is a medium-potency antipsychotic used for schizophrenia in addition to bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and nausea. It can cause extrapyramidal and anticholinergic symptoms, but this patient's agranulocytosis is not a typical adverse effect.
questions.hint: Other side effects of this drug include seizures (dose-dependent risk) and myocarditis.

questions.text: A 23-year old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother after trying to jump out of a moving car. He says that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been following him for the last 7 months. He recently quit his job at a local consulting firm to work on his mission to rid the world of evil and speaks excessively about his plan to “bring absolute justice to the world.” On mental status examination, his thought process is disorganized and his speech is pressured. A toxicology screen is negative. He is admitted to the hospital and treatment is initiated. One week later, he develops difficulty walking and a tremor that improves with activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's motor symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholinesterase inhibition is the mechanism of action for antidementia medications (e.g., donepezil). Considering the lack of memory dysfunction in this patient, cholinesterase inhibitors would not have been indicated, nor would they have caused EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

B) CORRECT:

Dopamine-2 receptor antagonism is the main mechanism of action for antipsychotics. All antipsychotics that interact with the D2 receptor can cause EPS, but this effect is particularly pronounced in the use of first-generation antipsychotics due to their high affinity to D2 receptors. Patients who have taken antipsychotics for days to weeks can develop features of pseudoparkinsonism, including tremors, rigidity, and shuffling gait. Antipsychotic-induced pseudoparkinsonism is managed by reducing the dose of the offending drug or switching to a second-generation antipsychotic. If dose reduction or switching is not possible, anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) or nonergot dopamine agonists (e.g., amantadine) can be used.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticholinergic agents (e.g., atropine, benztropine) cause the following side effects: confusion, agitation, hyperthermia, thirst, skin flushing, tachycardia, urinary retention, and dilated, nonreactive pupils. Anticholinergic agents would neither be indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

D) INCORRECT:

Among other indications, first-generation H1 antihistamines are used as sedatives to treat insomnia, and second-generation antihistamines are used as antiallergic agents to treat rhinitis and hypersensitivity reactions. The side effects of first-generation H1 antihistamines include sedation and anticholinergic effects, such as dry mouth and eyes, mydriasis, dizziness, tinnitus, urinary retention, and tachycardia. However, they would neither be indicated for schizophrenia nor cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

E) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. They can also be used to treat generalized anxiety disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder. However, they are neither routinely used for psychotic disorders, nor do they cause EPS such as this patient's pseudoparkinsonism.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the office by his mother for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he was started on increasing doses of risperidone because of behavioral changes. His mother now reports that he has become increasingly suspicious of the mail carrier, who he believes is “a secret agent from the CIA who is spying on our family.” He is currently at the maximum dose of risperidone. Previous treatment with quetiapine was not effective. His mother reports that she has seen him taking his medications regularly. He appears agitated. On mental status examination, he does not respond to any questions or instructions and continues to look to the left while nodding and smiling. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue medication and refer for cognitive behavioral therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term injectable (depot form) antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) may be considered in patients with schizophrenia with poor treatment adherence. This patient takes his medication regularly and, therefore, would not benefit from long-term injectable haloperidol.

B) CORRECT:

Clozapine is usually the first-line therapy for treatment-resistant schizophrenia because it is more effective than other antipsychotics. Clozapine is associated with an increased risk of agranulocytosis. Therefore, the benefits and risks of treatment, as well as the patient's ability to adhere to treatment and follow-ups, must be weighed and discussed with the patient and their family. Before initiating clozapine, the leukocyte count and differential should also be assessed; regular monitoring is indicated during treatment. Patients should have an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) > 1500 cells/μL before beginning treatment with clozapine. Additionally, monitoring for adverse metabolic effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia) is also recommended since atypical antipsychotics also increase the risk of metabolic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Electroconvulsive therapy and antipsychotic therapy are indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia in patients with low absolute neutrophil counts and for schizophrenia with catatonia, neither of which is the case here.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral lithium is a mood stabilizer that is indicated for both the acute and long-term management of mania. Although this patient is agitated and distracted, he lacks additional symptoms of mania (e.g., flight of ideas, elevated mood). Occasionally, other mood stabilizers, like lamotrigine, are used in combination with antipsychotics in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, oral lithium is not the first-line therapy in the management of such patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be used in combination with antipsychotic drugs in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, CBT is less effective when used alone.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is defined as ongoing positive symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) despite two antipsychotic trials of ≥ 6 weeks at the maximum dose.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago, he was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with trifluoperazine and cognitive behavioral therapy was initiated. He reports feeling better since starting treatment but has recently developed difficulty with his daily tasks as an administrative assistant, such as typing and picking up the phone. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows rigidity and shuffling gait. On mental status examination, his speech is normal, and his thought processes are linear with no disturbances of thought content or suicidal ideation. After discontinuing trifluoperazine, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy at this time?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is necessary at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is a very effective second-generation antipsychotic but is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (i.e., persistent symptoms despite taking 2 different antipsychotics at their maximum doses for ≥ 6 weeks) because of the risk for significant side effects (e.g., agranulocytosis).

B) CORRECT:

The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an FGA or a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) can be used. Because this patient developed extrapyramidal symptoms due to treatment with an FGA, the drug should be discontinued and treatment should be replaced by an SGA such as quetiapine. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Paliperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that can be used to treat schizophrenia. For maintenance therapy in schizophrenia, an intramuscular injection of a depot preparation of an antipsychotic is only considered if the patient has poor medication adherence to daily oral antipsychotic medication. This patient has no history of medication nonadherence.

An intramuscular antipsychotic injection is also used for the acute management of psychosis if the patient is severely agitated. This patient is calm and not in a psychotic state.

D) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency FGA that can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, this patient has previously developed extrapyramidal symptoms with an FGA. Therefore, a different treatment option should be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment. Discontinuing antipsychotic therapy puts the patient at risk of relapse.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia developed extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., pseudoparkinsonism) following treatment with trifluoperazine, a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA).

questions.text: After failing trials of multiple antipsychotics, a 35-year-old man with schizophrenia still experiences persistent auditory hallucinations and delusions. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic specifically indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, characterized by persistent psychotic symptoms despite trials of at least two other antipsychotics. It acts on multiple receptors, including dopamine D4 and serotonin 5-HT2, enhancing its efficacy in refractory cases. Clozapine also reduces suicidality risk in schizophrenia. However, it carries risks such as agranulocytosis, seizures, and myocarditis, necessitating regular monitoring of blood counts and metabolic parameters.

Key learning point: Clozapine is primarily used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is not typically used for bipolar disorder, substance abuse, or major depression.

B) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used primarily for bipolar disorder, targeting inositol monophosphatase and second messenger systems. It is not effective for primary psychotic symptoms in schizophrenia, which involve dopamine dysregulation. The absence of mood symptoms in this patient suggests that lithium is not appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is used for depression and anxiety disorders. It increases serotonin levels but does not target dopamine receptors involved in schizophrenia. The absence of depressive symptoms in this patient makes sertraline unsuitable for managing persistent psychotic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Disulfiram is used in alcohol use disorder by inhibiting acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, causing adverse reactions with alcohol. It does not address the dopaminergic and serotonergic imbalances in schizophrenia. Without evidence of alcohol use disorder, disulfiram is irrelevant to this patient's psychotic symptoms.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his mother due to 10 months of social withdrawal. He describes hearing voices warning him about conspiracies and believes neighbors are plotting against him. He denies depressed or manic symptoms and has no disorientation or confusion. He has no prior psychiatric history or known substance use. His functioning has markedly declined, resulting in job loss. Medical evaluation is unremarkable.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations or significant functional impairment. This patient has auditory hallucinations and marked social and occupational decline, which are inconsistent with delusional disorder.

B) CORRECT:

This patient exhibits core symptoms of schizophrenia, including persistent auditory hallucinations and persecutory delusions, along with significant social withdrawal and occupational decline over 10 months. Schizophrenia requires at least 6 months of symptoms, with an active phase presenting delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech. The absence of mood symptoms distinguishes it from schizoaffective disorder, while the chronicity and breadth of symptoms exceed the criteria for brief psychotic disorder. The presence of both hallucinations and delusions aligns with schizophrenia rather than delusional disorder. A normal medical evaluation rules out substance-induced or medical causes.

Key learning point: Auditory hallucinations and delusions of persecution are indicative of a psychotic disorder, such as schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder involves sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting more than one day but less than one month. The 10-month duration of this patient's symptoms contradicts the temporal criteria for this disorder, indicating a persistent rather than transient process.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder requires psychotic symptoms with prominent mood disturbances, such as major depressive or manic episodes. This patient lacks any mood symptoms, which are essential for a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder.

He has been symptom-free for eight months while taking a second-generation oral antipsychotic and reports minimal side effects. He regularly attends therapy sessions and lives with supportive family members. He asks how long he must remain on medication, expressing concern about the potential risks of continuing treatment indefinitely. Examination is normal, and vital signs are normal. Laboratory results are unchanged.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding his antipsychotic therapy?

choices.text: Add another oral agent to current regimen
Continue current medication for at least one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adding another antipsychotic is for inadequate response or treatment resistance. This patient is stable and symptom-free on monotherapy, with minimal side effects. Polypharmacy increases adverse effects without additional benefit in well-controlled patients. The absence of active symptoms or treatment failure does not warrant combining agents.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with schizophrenia who achieve symptomatic remission, maintaining antipsychotic therapy for at least one year is recommended to reduce relapse risk. Continued treatment stabilizes dopaminergic pathways and consolidates neurobiological adaptations. Clinical studies show that premature discontinuation increases relapse risk, negatively impacting long-term outcomes. Maintaining therapy reinforces early improvements, optimizing sustained remission and functional recovery.

Key learning point: In schizophrenia, maintenance therapy aims to improve quality of life and achieve long-lasting symptom reduction, with many patients experiencing satisfactory outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is stable, eight months of remission is insufficient for discontinuing antipsychotics. Schizophrenia has a high relapse risk if therapy is stopped prematurely. Guidelines suggest a minimum of 1–2 years of stability before considering tapering. Early discontinuation risks relapse, adversely affecting long-term prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-acting injectables benefit patients with adherence issues or relapse due to inconsistent oral use. This patient has stable symptoms, minimal side effects, and good adherence, supported by a strong support system. His concern is about long-term medication risks, not adherence, making injectables unnecessary.

questions.text: You are seeing a 27-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department from a homeless shelter due to bizarre behavior. He avoids contact with others and has told staff that he believes people are reading his mind. Three days ago, he unplugged all electrical appliances on his floor of the shelter because he thought they were being used to transmit messages about him. He has a diagnosis of schizophrenia and has been prescribed risperidone, but has been unable to take his medications regularly due to his unstable living situation. He appears disheveled and malodorous. His thought process is disorganized, and he does not make eye contact. Which one of the following is the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benztropine is used in the management of extrapyramidal syndromes associated with antipsychotic use (e.g., dystonia, akathisia), and intramuscular administration is preferred in the acute setting. However, this patient has none of these manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is used in the management of patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia, particularly those with persistent suicidality. This patient's symptoms are due to nonadherence rather than refractory schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral haloperidol, a first-generation typical antipsychotic, is used in the treatment of schizophrenia. However, this patient has already been prescribed risperidone (an atypical antipsychotic), and haloperidol is unlikely to be beneficial if he remains nonadherent.

D) INCORRECT:

Diazepam, a benzodiazepine, can be used in the management of acute extrapyramidal syndromes associated with antipsychotic use (e.g., dystonia, akathisia). However, this patient has none of these manifestations.

E) CORRECT:

Long-acting injectable antipsychotics, such as intramuscular (IM) risperidone, are the preferred pharmacologic strategy for treating patients with schizophrenia who have frequent relapses due to medication nonadherence. The use of long-acting injectable antipsychotics is associated with improved treatment adherence due to a reduced need for daily medications. IM risperidone is generally administered every 2 weeks but continues to be absorbed 4–6 weeks after injection.

Clozapine is typically reserved for use in treatment-resistant schizophrenia. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs (except for risperidone) have a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Key learning point: Lifelong antipsychotic therapy is typically required for schizophrenia; clozapine is reserved for treatment‑resistant cases, while all other agents are chosen based on patient profile and preference.
questions.hint: This patient with auditory hallucinations and delusions (ideas of reference, delusions of persecution) for more than 6 months meets the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. Three weeks ago, you diagnosed him with schizophrenia and started treatment with trifluoperazine and cognitive behavioral therapy. He reports improvement in his symptoms but has recently developed difficulty performing daily tasks at his job as an administrative assistant, such as typing and picking up the phone. Vital signs are normal. Neurologic examination reveals rigidity and a shuffling gait. On mental status examination, his speech is normal, and his thought processes are linear with no disturbances of thought content or suicidal ideation. After discontinuing trifluoperazine, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy at this time?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is necessary at this time.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment. Discontinuing antipsychotic therapy puts the patient at risk of relapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is a very effective second-generation antipsychotic but is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (i.e., persistent symptoms despite taking 2 different antipsychotics at their maximum doses for ≥ 6 weeks) because of the risk for significant side effects (e.g., agranulocytosis).

C) CORRECT:

The choice of antipsychotic for the treatment of schizophrenia depends on the patient's profile and preferences; either an FGA or a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) can be used. Because this patient developed extrapyramidal symptoms due to treatment with an FGA, the drug should be discontinued and treatment should be replaced by an SGA such as quetiapine. In contrast to FGAs, SGAs carry a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. SGAs, especially olanzapine and clozapine, have an increased risk of metabolic side effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia).

Patients with schizophrenia typically require lifelong antipsychotic therapy even if there is an adequate response to initial treatment.

Key learning point: Second-generation antipsychotics like quetiapine are preferred over first-generation agents for schizophrenia in patients who develop extrapyramidal symptoms, due to their lower risk of movement-related side effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a high-potency FGA that can be used to treat schizophrenia. However, this patient has previously developed extrapyramidal symptoms with an FGA. Therefore, a different treatment option should be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Paliperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic medication used to treat schizophrenia. While intramuscular injection of a depot preparation of an antipsychotic can be considered for maintenance therapy, it is more commonly used in situations where medication adherence is a concern. In this case, the patient has no history of nonadherence to medication.

An intramuscular antipsychotic injection is also used for the acute management of psychosis, particularly if the patient is severely agitated. However, this patient is calm and not exhibiting any signs of a psychotic state.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia developed extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., pseudoparkinsonism) following treatment with trifluoperazine, a first-generation antipsychotic (FGA).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who is a college student is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for increasingly bizarre behavior over the past 2 weeks. The patient has been skipping classes, isolating himself in his room, and expressing concerns that his professors are monitoring him through surveillance devices. He appears disheveled, with flat affect, and responds to questions with minimal, disorganized responses. His roommate reports the patient was previously a high-achieving student with no psychiatric history. Vital signs are normal. Initial laboratory studies, including CBC, BMP, liver chemistries, thyroid function tests, and urine toxicology, are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge to family with crisis intervention team follow-up
Observe in emergency department for 6 hours then reassess
Discharge home with outpatient psychiatry follow-up within 48 hours
Admit to inpatient psychiatry unit for further evaluation
Transfer to medical floor for further diagnostic workup

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crisis intervention team follow-up is insufficient for first-episode psychosis. The patient requires immediate inpatient psychiatric care for comprehensive evaluation and treatment initiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Extended emergency department observation is inappropriate for first-episode psychosis. This patient requires urgent psychiatric consultation and inpatient admission for comprehensive evaluation and treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is inappropriate for first-episode psychosis. The patient shows severe symptoms and functional impairment requiring immediate psychiatric evaluation and inpatient stabilization.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Patients experiencing a first episode of psychosis should be hospitalized. This patient shows classic features of primary psychosis, including paranoid delusions, negative symptoms, and significant functional decline over 2 weeks. With organic causes ruled out by normal laboratory studies and vital signs, psychiatric hospitalization is indicated for comprehensive evaluation and treatment initiation.

E) INCORRECT:

Transfer to medical floor is unnecessary since organic causes have been ruled out with normal vital signs and laboratory studies. This patient requires specialized psychiatric care rather than general medical management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the outpatient psychiatric clinic by his mother because of a 3-year history of progressive social withdrawal, disorganized thoughts, and auditory hallucinations. His symptoms began subtly during his final year of college, leading to a decline in his academic performance and eventually to dropping out. He frequently talks to himself, laughs inappropriately, and expresses paranoid delusions about being watched by government agencies. His past medical history is unremarkable. He denies any substance use, and there is no family history of psychiatric illness. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows poor hygiene and grooming. He is disoriented in time and place. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and urine toxicology screen, are within normal limits. Which of the following neuroimaging findings is associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caudate nucleus atrophy is the hallmark neuroimaging finding in Huntington disease, a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder characterized by choreiform movements, psychiatric disturbances, and cognitive decline. This patient's clinical features suggest schizophrenia, which is not associated with caudate nucleus atrophy.

B) CORRECT:

Enlargement of the lateral ventricles is a common and consistently replicated structural brain abnormality found in individuals with schizophrenia. This structural change reflects loss of cortical volume due to neuronal atrophy and is thought to underlie the cognitive and negative symptoms of the disorder. Other common findings include cortical atrophy and decreased hippocampal and/or temporal mass.

Brain imaging is not required for the diagnosis of schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral atrophy of the mammillary bodies is characteristic of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a complication of chronic thiamine deficiency that is typically seen in alcohol use disorder. This syndrome manifests with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (Wernicke encephalopathy), and progresses to memory impairment and confabulation (Korsakoff psychosis), none of which are seen here. This patient's clinical features suggest schizophrenia, which is not associated with atrophy of the mammillary bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Basal ganglia calcifications are associated with rare conditions such as Fahr disease and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., hypoparathyroidism). Schizophrenia is not associated with basal ganglia calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Diffuse cerebral edema is seen in acute encephalopathies due to trauma, hypoxia, infections, or metabolic disturbances, and typically manifests with rapid-onset altered mental status, decreased consciousness, and often with focal neurological deficits. Chronic, progressive psychosis and functional decline without acute neurological changes or systemic illness suggest schizophrenia, which is not associated with diffuse cerebral edema.
questions.hint: The presence of positive symptoms (auditory hallucinations, delusions), negative symptoms (social withdrawal), and a chronic functional decline since early adulthood suggests schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his parents due to an 8-month history of progressive social withdrawal and bizarre behavior. His parents report that he has isolated himself, quit his part-time job, and his grades have plummeted. He speaks of a conspiracy by his professors to fail him and often mutters to himself, seemingly responding to unheard voices. He is poorly groomed, makes poor eye contact, and appears internally preoccupied. Mental status examination shows a blunted affect and tangential speech that is difficult to follow. A urine toxicology screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Bipolar I disorder with psychotic features
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although psychosis can occur in bipolar I disorder, it happens in the context of a distinct manic episode. This patient's history does not mention classic manic symptoms such as elevated mood, grandiosity, a decreased need for sleep, or pressured speech. The psychosis appears to be the primary and continuous disturbance, not secondary to a mood episode.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder presents with the same symptoms as schizophrenia. However, the diagnostic criteria specify a symptom duration of at least 1 month but less than 6 months. Because this patient's symptoms have been ongoing for 8 months, it is inconsistent with schizophreniform disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizoaffective disorder meet the criteria for schizophrenia and also have concurrent major mood episodes (depressive or manic). Although the patient has a blunted affect, his symptoms are inconsistent with a full major depressive or manic episode. For schizoaffective disorder, mood symptoms must be present for the majority of the total duration of the illness.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with schizophrenia. He exhibits positive symptoms (persecutory delusions, auditory hallucinations), negative symptoms (social withdrawal, blunted affect), and disorganized speech (tangentiality). Crucially, these symptoms have caused significant social and occupational dysfunction (job loss, poor grades) and have been present for 8 months. The diagnosis of schizophrenia requires at least two characteristic symptoms for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period, with continuous signs of the disturbance persisting for at least 6 months. The absence of a prominent mood episode and a negative toxicology screen further support this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of major depressive disorder with psychotic features requires the patient to meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode, with psychotic symptoms occurring exclusively during the mood episode. The patient's blunted affect and social withdrawal could be seen in depression, but he does not have any other core depressive symptoms, such as persistent low mood or anhedonia. The prominent disorganized speech and bizarre behavior are more characteristic of a primary psychotic disorder.
questions.hint: The diagnosis of primary psychotic disorders often hinges on the duration of symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with treatment-resistant schizophrenia presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and malaise. He was started on a new medication 2 months ago after unsuccessful trials of two other antipsychotics. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), his pulse is 115/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema without exudates. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 1.2 × 10⁹/L, hemoglobin of 14.1 g/dL, a platelet count of 220 × 10⁹/L, and an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of 450/µL. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clozapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is uniquely effective for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Its use is limited by a significant risk of life-threatening agranulocytosis, a severe form of neutropenia. This patient's presentation with fever and sore throat, coupled with a dangerously low ANC of 450/µL, is a classic manifestation of this adverse effect. The signs of infection are a direct result of the compromised immune system. Due to this risk, patients on clozapine must be enrolled in a mandatory registry that requires regular ANC monitoring, especially during the first several months of therapy, when the risk is highest.

B) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is a commonly used second-generation antipsychotic. Although it can cause leukopenia or neutropenia, this side effect is much less common and typically less severe than with other agents. It is not the first-line treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, making it a less likely choice for a patient who has had unsuccessful trials of two other antipsychotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic. Agranulocytosis is a rare but possible side effect of this medication. However, haloperidol is not the agent most strongly associated with this adverse event. Furthermore, a patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has typically had unsuccessful trials of second-generation agents and would be advanced to a more effective medication, not a first-generation one.

D) INCORRECT:

Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used for depression and anxiety disorders, not as a primary treatment for schizophrenia. Although rare cases of neutropenia have been reported with SSRIs, it is not a characteristic side effect, and this medication does not fit the clinical context of treating refractory schizophrenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used primarily for bipolar disorder, not schizophrenia. A key side effect of lithium is leukocytosis, which is an increase in the WBC count. This patient's laboratory findings show severe leukopenia and neutropenia, which is the opposite of what would be expected with lithium's side effects.
questions.hint: The diagnosis of treatment-resistant schizophrenia significantly narrows the likely medication choices. Consider which antipsychotic carries a black box warning for severe neutropenia and requires strict hematologic monitoring.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his sister because she noticed he has been behaving differently over the past 4 weeks. Today, the patient attempted to set their house on fire while yelling that he was trying to “save us all.” The patient has a history of psychotic symptoms treated with aripiprazole. His sister states that he stopped taking his medications about 3 weeks ago. He works as a dishwasher but has not been to work for several days. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows a blunted affect. Throughout the interview, the patient continuously stares at the ceiling and makes little eye contact. When asked about the incident today, he states that he has been hearing the voice of “the great one” who has informed him that aliens are in his neighborhood in the form of rats and cockroaches that need to be “torched to prevent the alien invasion.” He is refusing treatment and insists on going home. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer the patient to a psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy
Report the patient to the local police
Ask the patient's sister to convince him to stay overnight

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Risperidone injected intramuscularly every 2 weeks (i.e., depot therapy) is a long-term treatment option for patients with schizophrenia who have a history of poor adherence. This patient's nonadherence with oral pharmacological treatment makes him a good candidate for maintenance therapy with long-acting injectable antipsychotics, which should be started following initial stabilization in order to prevent future relapse. However, at this point, he is experiencing an acute psychotic episode and requires more urgent treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Referral to a psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy is an important adjunctive treatment for patients with schizophrenia, as it helps to avoid relapse of psychotic symptoms. However, this patient is experiencing an acute psychotic episode and requires more urgent treatment.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing an acute psychotic episode, during which he tried to set his house on fire. Because he represents an immediate danger to himself and to others, the most appropriate next step would be to involuntarily hospitalize him and initiate treatment with short-acting antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, haloperidol). This patient's history of nonadherence with oral pharmacological treatment makes him a good candidate for maintenance therapy with long-acting injectable antipsychotics, which should be started following initial stabilization to prevent future relapse.

D) INCORRECT:

Reporting the patient to the local police is not appropriate, as this patient is experiencing an acute psychotic episode and requires immediate medical treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

While convincing the patient to voluntarily stay overnight may improve his adherence and help to establish a therapeutic relationship, it is not appropriate to place this responsibility on his sister. Furthermore, voluntariness is not required for hospitalization of this patient as he is acutely psychotic and represents a danger to himself and to others, evidenced by the attempt to set his house on fire.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of psychotic illness presents with auditory hallucinations, delusions, blunted affect, and apathetic behavior, strongly suggesting an acute psychotic episode of schizophrenia.
